Documentation of dict_diff¶

dict_diff.add_different(orig: dict, other: dict, equivalent_func=<function equivalent>)¶
Returns:

the dict, where all of other’s keys values not equivalent() to ones in orig are present. If the value of a key is a dict, only non equivalent() parts of that dictionary are present

This is faster than remove_equivalent(), if the difference between the dicts is small

dict_diff.apply_diff(orig: dict, diff: dict)¶

Applies the diff to orig

Parameters:

  • orig – The original dict

  • diff – The diff to apply

Returns:

a dict, so that apply_diff(something, dict_diff(something, other)) is equivalent() to other

dict_diff.dict_diff(orig: dict, other: dict, removing=False, equivalent_func=<function equivalent>)¶
Parameters:

  • orig – The original dict

  • other – The dict the diff is taken of

  • removing – If this method uses remove_equivalent() or add_different(), defaults to False

  • equivalent_func – This method is used for determining if two elements (of any types) are equivalent, defaults to equivalent()

Returns:

The diff, so that apply_diff(orig, diff) returns something equivalent() to other

Return type:

dict

You can directly use add_different() or remove_equivalent() to circumvent one if-statement

dict_diff.dict_equivalent(dict1: dict, dict2: dict)¶
Returns:

True if and only if all members of the dicts are equivalent()

Return type:

bool

dict_diff.equivalent(element1, element2)¶
Returns:

True if and only if:

  • The types of element1 and element2 are the same

    • For lists: if the lists are equal regardless of order

    • For dicts: if all members are equivalent

    • For everything else: if element1 == element2

Return type:

bool

dict_diff.find_different(orig: dict, other: dict, equivalent_func=<function equivalent>)¶
Returns:

a list of keys k whose values are not equivalent() in orig and other, such that k is a subset of other’s keys

dict_diff.find_equivalent(orig: dict, other: dict, equivalent_func=<function equivalent>)¶
Returns:

a list of keys k whose values are equivalent() in orig and other, such that k is a subset of orig’s and other’s keys

dict_diff.list_unordered_equal(list1: list, list2: list)¶
Returns:

True if and only if each value in list1 has exactly one equivalent() value in list2

Return type:

bool

dict_diff.remove_equivalent(orig: dict, other: dict, equivalent_func=<function equivalent>)¶
Returns:

the dict, where all of other’s keys values equivalent() to ones in orig have been removed. If the value of a key is a dict, all equivalent() parts of that dictionary are removed as well

This is faster than add_different(), if the difference between the dicts is large

Dictionary diff
